title: 111_s4033
content: The Act is titled the "Restoration of Legal Rights for Claimants under Holocaust-Era Insurance Policies Act of 2010" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2. The Act aims to enforce State laws on disclosing information about Holocaust-era insurance policies, allowing citizens to know their rights under the policies. The Act allows US citizens to sue in US courts to recover proceeds from Holocaust-era insurance policies, overriding any preemptive foreign policy defenses. It also prevents defenses based on prior judgments or settlements that wrongly concluded State-law claims are preempted by foreign policy. The Act allows US citizens to sue in US courts to recover proceeds from Holocaust-era insurance policies, overriding preemptive foreign policy defenses and preserving Congress's lawmaking powers under the Constitution. It also establishes a uniform statute of limitations of 10 years for such actions. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, a "beneficiary" includes a named insured, named beneficiary, heir, assignee, or legal representative under a covered policy. A "covered policy" refers to any insurance policy in effect between January 31, 1933, and December 31, 1945, issued to a policyholder domiciled in areas occupied by Nazi Germany or Switzerland. The curr_chunk discusses the definitions of "insurer" and "Nazi Germany" within the context of the Act. An insurer is defined as a person engaged in the business of insurance who issued a covered policy, including any successor in interest. Nazi Germany is defined as the Nazi government of Germany and any government with friendly relations, allied with, or controlled by Nazi Germany, or claiming sovereignty over occupied areas. The curr_chunk defines "related company" as an affiliate under the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act. SEC. 4. PRIVATE RIGHT OF ACTION; CIVIL ACTIONS. Beneficiaries of covered policies can sue insurers or related companies to recover policy proceeds or enforce policy rights. Process serving for such civil actions can be done nationwide. Courts must award prevailing beneficiaries the proceeds due under the covered policy in these actions. In civil actions, beneficiaries of covered policies can sue insurers for policy proceeds and rights enforcement. Courts must award prevailing beneficiaries the proceeds due under the policy, prejudgment interest, any necessary relief, treble damages for bad faith actions, and attorney's fees and costs. The prevailing beneficiary in a civil action can receive attorney's fees and costs. A civil action must be filed within 10 years of the Act's enactment. SEC. 5. EFFECT OF PRIOR JUDGMENTS AND RELEASES. A judgment or release under this section shall not prevent any person from bringing a claim under section 4, regardless of any prior agreements or judgments related to covered policies in civil actions. The section outlines rules regarding agreements between claimants and the International Commission on Holocaust Era Insurance Claims or insurers. It specifies that agreements denominated as releases, discharges, or waivers are valid, except for those labeled as humanitarian payments. The curr_chunk mentions the International Commission on Holocaust Era Insurance Claims. SEC. 6. EFFECT OF EXECUTIVE AGREEMENTS AND EXECUTIVE FOREIGN POLICY. The effect of executive agreements and executive foreign policy on state laws and claims brought under this act is outlined. Executive agreements and foreign policies shall not override state laws related to claims against insurers or disclosure requirements. They also shall not compromise or waive claims brought under the act. The text explains that executive agreements and executive foreign policies will not prevent claims under section 4 of the act. Executive agreements are agreements between the US and a foreign government, while executive foreign policies are foreign policies of the executive branch. SEC. 7. EFFECT ON STATE LAWS. This Act does not override State laws unless they conflict with it. SEC. 8. TIMELINESS OF ACTIONS UNDER STATE LAW. Claims under State laws described in section 6(a) are not considered untimely if filed within 10 years of this Act's enactment. SEC. 9. SEVERABILITY. If any part of this Act is deemed unconstitutional, the rest remains unaffected. SEC. 10. EFFECTIVE DATE; APPLICABILITY. SEC. 10. EFFECTIVE DATE; APPLICABILITY. This Act takes effect on the date of enactment and applies to any claim related to a covered policy brought before, on, or after the enactment date.
